description.plain:
Erica Abi Wright, better know as the Erykah Badu is a multi-genre artist with influences spanning from Hip-Hop, R&B, Soul, Funk and Experimental. She is credited as one of the pioneers of Neo-Soul movement of the mid 90’s and would become one of the most prolific artist of the genre, earning her the title “First Lady Of Neo-Soul.”

Erykah’s career began in 1994, when she opened a show for D'angelo, and attracted the attention of Kedar Entertainment. Under the label, Erykah would release her debut alum Baduizm, which earned two Grammy awards. Erykah would use the monumentum of the debut release to create one of the strongest discographies of any R&B artist.

songs.title: On & On

description.plain:
Erykah Badu’s debut single “On & On” is a signature song of the Neo Soul era and displayed a Billie Holiday influence in her vocal style. The gold single peaked at #12 on the Billboard Hot 100 and topped both the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs and UK Singles charts. The song also won a Grammy Award for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance in 1998.

Like many other figures in 90’s hip-hop, Erykah explored the teachings of the Nation of Gods and Earths (also known as the Five Percent Nation), referencing the group’s theology of Supreme Mathematics.

The lyrical and melodic themes of “On & On” were continued on the track “…& On” on her follow-up album, Mama’s Gun.

songs.title: Hello

description.plain:
This track from Erykah’s But U Caint Use My Phone mixtape marks another collaboration between Ms. Badu and 3 Stacks – the ex-lovers who previously collaborated to make OutKast’s “Liberation” and “Humble Mumble", as well as coming together to make their son—Seven Sirius Benjamin.

“Hello” gives us André’s first verse of 2015, and only his fourth since 2012. The remaining verses are the duo’s version of The Isley Brothers‘ 1974 song “Hello It’s Me.” The song was originally recorded by rock singer Todd Rundgren in 1972.

songs.title: Tyrone

description.plain:
Erykah told the Power 105 Breakfast Club that her most famous song was “a total freestyle” that she made up on the spot and just happened to record.

Erykah has had enough with her no-good, do-nothing man and is kicking him out of the house. Tyrone isn’t actually the boyfriend here: Tyrone is the boyfriend’s homeboy, and Erykah suggests that he “call up Tyrone” to help him move his shit out of her house.

The boyfriend put his friends above her, disrespected her, and basically acted like a scrub. Since he loves Tyrone so much, maybe Tyrone can help him carry his things out: but he can’t call Tyrone on Erykah’s phone, because he never helped her with the bill.

Some have suggested that this song is about Andre 3000 of Outkast, an allegation that he vehemently denies in his song “A Life in the Day of Benjamin Andre.”

songs.title: Bag Lady

description.plain:
Lyrics by Badu, music by Badu and Andre Young. Production by Badu and James Poyser.

In this song, Badu sings to women who carry around emotional baggage from past relationships in which men did not treat them as they should have. Badu sings from the heart and with a lot of feeling.

songs.title: Next Lifetime

description.plain: “Next Lifetime” is the second single from Baduizm and talks about a woman that is in a relationship but has feelings for another man. The music video features cameos from her boyfriend at the time, Andre 3000, as well as rapper Method Man and rapper/producer Pete Rock. The single topped the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay chart and reached the Top 40 in New Zealand and the UK.

songs.full_title: Didn't Cha Know by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Didn’t Cha Know

description.plain:
Erykah Badu and producer J. Dilla come together on “Didn’t Cha Know”, the second single from Mama’s Gun. The song samples Tarika Blue’s 1977 song “Dreamflower”, which was unauthorized, leading to an out of court settlement. The single reached #28 on Billboard’s Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart and was nominated in the Best R&B Song category at the Grammy Awards in 2001. Erykah talked about how she and Dilla created this track:

I met him through Common. Common and he were good friends and I went to Detroit because I wanted him to be on my album. I didn’t know in what way, but you always hope something works out great and if not you’ll be good friends. … Dilla goes, ‘OK, I want you to look for a record.’ I’m looking through these organized, tightly packed crates, and I just pulled out one record and the artist was Tarika Blue. I liked that name. I put on the first track [“Dreamflower”] and I fell in love with the song and I kept playing it over and over again and I said, ‘I want this.’ He showed me how to loop a small part of the bassline. … Then I left the room and when I came back he had looped some drums to a small sample of the song and I started to write to it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yDBIvE9J4xk

“Didn’t Cha Know” begins a medley that spans the record’s first side—"My Life", “… & On”, and “Cleva”.

songs.full_title: Love of My Life (An Ode To Hip Hop) by Erykah Badu (Ft. Common)
songs.title: Love of My Life (An Ode To Hip Hop)
songs.title_with_featured: Love of My Life (An Ode To Hip Hop) (Ft. Common)

description.plain:
“Love of My Life (An Ode to Hip-Hop)” is the second collaboration between Erykah Badu and Common, following Erykah’s appearance on Common’s 1998 track “All Night Long”. “Love of My Life” won a Grammy Award for Best R&B Song and topped Billboard’s Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart for a month, while peaking at #9 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The song was also released as a single from the Brown Sugar soundtrack. The link between hip-hop and love was a Soulquarian theme, with evident crossover and multi-inter-referencing:


Firstly, “Love of My Life”,  references “Act Too (Love of My Life)” by The Roots in the song title, as well at the beginning of the song’s music video:



https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=dNk3R23Twgw


“Love of My Life” also features Common, one of Erykah’s high-profile ex-boyfriends, who originally performed:



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C99iG4HoO1c


“I Used To Love H.E.R”, is referenced by “Love of My Life” both thematically (as both equate hip-hop to a lover)  and in its music video, bringing us full circle…
Common also features in “Act Too (Love of My Life)”, in which he and Black Thought discuss their history with hip-hop.

songs.title: Appletree

description.plain: In “Appletree”, Badu alludes that her wisdom and knowledge are like fruits which she is offering freely. Ultimately, if certain people don’t want to spend time with her, they are rejecting these gifts. The song was released in US as a radio promo and as an official single in Europe.

songs.title: Otherside of the Game

description.plain: “Otherside of the Game” is a about being a dopeman’s girl and weighing the morality of the situation as she is expecting a child with the man. In the music video, Badu plays opposite her boyfriend at the time, Andre 3000 from OutKast, with whom she was expecting their son, Seven, when the video was shot. The single peaked at #57 on Billboard’s Hot R&B/Hip-Hop/Rap Songs chart and #14 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay chart.

songs.title: Window Seat

description.plain:
The lead single from Erykah Badu’s New Amerykah Part Two (Return of the Ankh) deals with isolation and the need to get away over a melancholy melody. The song peaked at #16 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. She later released a remix with Rick Ross, which was featured in a music video along with “Turn Me Away (Get Munny)”.

Badu was charged with disorderly conduct for appearing nude in Dealey Plaza in Dallas, during the filming of her music video and public performance. She had to pay a $500 fine. However, she made a statement. Badu described the song as:

Liberating yourself from layers and layers of skin or demons that are a hindrance to your growth or freedom, or evolution. I wanted to do something that said just that, so I started to think about shedding, nudity, taking things off in a very artful way. — source

songs.title: Green Eyes

description.plain: Badu closes out Mama’s Gun with a song detailing stages involved in dealing with a relationship that has ended. The three suites involve first dealing with the “green-eyed monster” of jealousy along with denial, accepting that the relationship is over, but then attempting to rekindle the flame. Musically, the song starts with an old time blues sound reminiscent of Billie Holiday before going into a melancholy melody and ending with a more upbeat track.

songs.embed_content: Read “Green Eyes” by Erykah Badu on Genius

body.plain: Badu closes out Mama’s Gun with a song detailing stages involved in dealing with a relationship that has ended. The three suites involve first dealing with the “green-eyed monster” of jealousy along with denial, accepting that the relationship is over, but then attempting to rekindle the flame. Musically, the song starts with an old time blues sound reminiscent of Billie Holiday before going into a melancholy melody and ending with a more upbeat track.

songs.title: ...& On

description.plain: “…& On” is a sequel to her 1997 breakthrough hit single “On & On”, for which Erykah was awarded Best Female R&B Vocal Performance at the 1998 Grammy Awards. As she did in “On & On”, Erykah incorporates principles from the Nation of Gods and Earth (a.k.a. the Five Percent Nation) but she questions the effectiveness of a message if it goes over people’s heads.

songs.full_title: Cel U Lar Device by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Cel U Lar Device

description.plain:
Surprise! R&B singer and neo-soul originator Erykah Badu came out with a cover of Drake’s “Hotline Bling” on October 1, 2015.

After releasing a free mixtape in July 2015 consisting of “carefully and lovingly selected high frequency tones for the soul.”, Erykah released the Zach Witness-produced “Hotline Bling” (later retitled “Cel U Lar Device”) as the lead single from her mixtape/concept album But U Caint Use My Phone.

The song consists of 3 parts: the verse & chorus of “Hotline Bling,” a comedic voicemail skit by Erykah, and a reworked groove where Erykah re-interprets the verse and freestyles over it.

For the commercial release of “Cell U Lar Device,” the third part was edited down by about one-minute, cutting out a repeated verse and chorus, as well as an incidental sample of Outkast’s “Ms. Jackson.”

https://twitter.com/ZachWitness/status/650008554858934272
https://twitter.com/ZachWitness/status/650010252083990528

songs.title: Rimshot (Intro)

description.plain:
The intro track to Erykah Badu’s acclaimed debut album revolves around a sexual innuendo about drumming.

For those who don’t know, a rimshot is when a drummer hits the center and the rim of the snare at once. Of course the drumming in this song features rimshots.

songs.title: Orange Moon

description.plain:
Lyrics by Badu. Music by Badu, Bray Lon Lacy and Shaun Martin. Production by Badu and James Poyser.

Track 10 on Mama’s Gun, “Orange Moon” is a jazz-influenced love ballad. As on previous songs, Badu’s lyrics employ the imagery and symbolism of teachings of the Five-Percent Nation, the Supreme Alphabet and Supreme Mathematics.



In Five-Percent symbolism, the sun and moon represent the Black man/masculinity and Black woman/femininity, respectively, while the star represents the Black child.

By the time of the recording of Mama’s Gun Erykah was in a relationship with rapper Common, also a follower of Five-Percent teachings. Erykah and Common were both associated with the Soulquarians collective, who collaborated on the recording and production of both Mama’s Gun and Common’s 2000 album Like Water for Chocolate. Several lyrics in Common’s 2000 single “The Light” from Like Water for Chocolate employ mutual sun/moon imagery in a similar romantic context.

songs.title: Certainly

description.plain:
Two versions of “Certainly” are featured on Baduizm: the original jazzy beat, and a flipped version that samples Kool & the Gang’s “Summer Madness”. This song can be interpreted in at least three different ways:


Erykah Badu said that the main theme of the song is how Africans were brought to America and forced to change their culture.
Another theme is a single woman that isn’t looking for love, and can do bad by herself. And occasionally a man comes by trying to make her believe that she needs him, but she wakes up and realizes she doesn’t need him there to be complete.
And third, in the songs most literal sense the song is about a woman that is out on a casual date with a man, and when she isn’t paying attention he slips a ‘Micky Finn’ (Date Rape Drug) into her drink. Earlier he wasn’t touching her, but “Now you wanna kiss me”.

Track 5 off of Erykah Badu’s album titled “New Amerykah, Pt 1”. The song discusses subject matter involving racial inequality and black oppression.

The flute sample is taken directly from “Theme” by Solution

songs.full_title: Time's a Wastin' by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Time’s a Wastin’

description.plain: “Time’s a Wastin'” is another Mama’s Gun track displaying a theme of lost love and injustice, serving as a message to young black men about the perils of living in a world with constant reminders that it doesn’t love them and will be even more harsh to them if they don’t establish a solid life plan.

songs.full_title: Back in the Day (Puff) by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Back in the Day (Puff)

description.plain:
The second single released off of Erykah’s third album Worldwide Underground, “Back in the Day” is a funky jam that finds Ms. Badu reminiscing about the good old days when puffing on good weed was all they needed to have a good time. The single peaked at #62 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. She performed the song live for Dave Chappelle’s Block Party in 2004.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QySrbts0OYA

songs.title: Danger

description.plain:
The lead single from Worldwide Underground, “Danger” paints the picture of what life is like as a hustler’s woman. On her debut album, Baduizm, the single “Otherside of the Game” shows her being more concerned about the negative repercussions of her man’s occupation, but here, she’s more confident and probably gets her own hands dirty if need be. The single peaked at #27 on Billboard’s Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.

The live version paints a more vivid picture of the song’s message:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ghJ6yAtnyg8

songs.full_title: I'll Call U Back by Erykah Badu
songs.title: I’ll Call U Back

description.plain:
“I’ll Call U Back” is an interlude on Erykah Badu’s But U Caint Use My Phone mixtape. Though it uses the same backing track from her “Hotline Bling” remake entitled “Cell U Lar Device”, instead of reprising Drake’s lyrics, Erykah does another one of her trademark freestyles.

Continuing the prevailing theme of Caint Use My Phone, this bit of verse is about prioritizing life outside of her electronic device. Her last words echo into the rhythmic sound of a busy dial tone as the track ends.

songs.title: Penitentiary Philosophy

description.plain:
In the opening track from Mama’s Gun, Erykah explains how

We lock ourselves into our own philosophies, our own religions, our own walks of life, and if we fail, we condemn ourselves and then we get sick. I think that if we can find a way to clear our minds free and be a little freer and not lock ourselves into things, because I think we’re afraid of change. I think a lot of people have lost respect for the individual, you know, the individual, the person who doesn’t conform. It’s a jail. It’s like, if you don’t be this way when you go to work, so and so is gonna talk about you. If I don’t do this, someone was like, “We live a commercial every day for the world”. It’s unnecessary. And I’m tired of doing it. So I wanted to write a song about it.



The song came out of a session with James Poyser, Questlove and Pino Palladino, where Erykah “freestyled the lyrics”.
The singer claims that she only found out what she meant with the song only later on.

songs.title: Cleva

description.plain: A proponent of living naturally, Erykah reflects on how she places more value in having a beautiful mind over presenting a beautiful physical appearance. This message is underlied by a jazzy musical selection courtesy of the Soulquarians, along with vibes from the legendary Roy Ayers.

songs.title: Honey

description.plain:
Erykah Badu connects with producer 9th Wonder for the lead single from her fourth studio album, New Amerykah Part One (4th World War). “Honey” is based around a sample from Nancy Wilson’s “I’m in Love”. The single peaked at #22 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.

The music video is set in a small record store and follows a customer (whom is Badu) looking through old-school vintage R&B, hip-hop, and rock albums, with the albums' cover artwork depicted as moving images with Badu cast in them. Some of the albums featured in the video include: Funkadelic’s Maggot Brain, Nas‘ Illmatic, De La Soul’s 3 Feet High and Rising, and many more. Video director Chris Robinson said the “album covers represent all the influences that she embodies.” The video won an MTV Video Music Award for Best Direction.

songs.title: A.D. 2000

description.plain:
“A.D. 2000” is a poignant tribute to 22-year-old Guinean immigrant Amadou Diallo, who was shot dead by four plain-clothed members of the New York City Police Department in February, 1999.



Diallo, a street merchant by day and student by night, was outside his apartment in the Bronx on the night of February 5, when he was spotted by four NYPD officers who believed he matched the description of a serial rapist who had been active in the burrough. The officers alleged that they had identified themselves clearly to Diallo, who had run; claiming to have mistaken the wallet he was carrying for a gun, the officers fired a total of 41 shots, 19 of which hit Diallo. Racial profiling, gross negligence and other civil rights violations by the officers were alleged.

All four officers were indicted for second-degree murder, but were subsequently acquitted by a jury in Albany, New York in February 2000, after the trial was moved due to claims that media coverage of the shooting had made a fair trial in New York City impossible. Diallo’s family were awarded a $3,000,000 settlement from the City of New York in a subsequent wrongful death claim.

Badu wrote “A.D. 2000” from the perspective of Diallo. The initialism of the title refers to his name and date of death, Badu explaining:

I didn’t want to call attention to [the name] because so many people were doing songs to Amadou Diallo… So I’d rather do as it as his words, ‘Say, you won’t be naming no buildings after me, to go down dilapidated’.

The title also refers to the year 2000 using the abbreviated Latin term for numbering years, “Anno Domini", meaning "in the year of our lord”, with the year A.D. 1 referring to the traditionally designated date of the birth of Jesus of Nazareth.

The album release notes credit the writing of the song to “The Wright Sisters”. Soul singer Betty Wright co-wrote the song and contributed backing vocals; Erykah is credited for her contribution under her birth name, Erica Wright.

songs.title: Booty

description.plain:
Music and lyrics by Badu. Production by Badu and James Poyser.

Track 7 on Mama’s Gun, “Booty” deals with infidelity. In the song, Erykah addresses another woman, reminding her of all the ways she could take her man with relative ease – but she doesn’t want to, because she’s not interested in a man who would cheat on his partner. She hopes the other woman would have the same respect for Erykah’s relationship if put in her position – seemingly implying that the reverse situation has already occured, and the woman didn’t have the same regard for Erykah.

Questlove on drums and J Dilla on bass contribute a funky rhythm section to the song, which interpolates elements from Johnny Hammond’s “Gambler’s Life”.
http://youtu.be/QF3W0kuBPAE?t=39s

Mama’s Gun album closer “Green Eyes” also addresses infidelity.

description.plain: This song is the third installment of a story about a fictional character created by Badu about a woman in love with a hustler and the tribulations she experiences by being with him. The first is ‘Other Side of the Game’ from Baduizm and the second is ‘Danger’ from Worldwide Underground.

songs.lyrics:
Friends, fans, and artists must meet LyricsFriends, fans, artists must meet
Which one are you, which one is me?
Friends, fans, and artist must meet
Which one are you, which one are me?

FANS
God, please, o, please let her breathe my way
If she sing my song today I can be okay
See I understand the message in the song she write
I was really happy for her when she won tonight
She a rebel for the struggle, fighting just like me
I know she down to sing at the cookout for free
I was kinda disappointed with the song she wrote
Went to her website, wrote a long ass note
She done made a million dollars, but she down to earth
She be rocking Chuck Taylors and a thrift sto' purse
Signing autographs 'til the park was dark
I know it's kinda hard when they love your art
In the magazines they be twisting up the facts
But her response was fair, I like how she come back
She be sanging for the world, sharing all her pain
When she fell up in the game she had changed
Fans, friends, artist must meet
Which one are you which 1 are me

FRIENDS
Folk in the face like she ain't the same
Still the same bitch, she just changed her name
She don't really like to hang around with us no mo '
Wasn't nothing like that back in '94
She be falling in the spot with a fat aass grin
Now she roll a Benz, she don't need no friends

Don't nobody really understand that shit she write
She done made a million dollars ,she can give us some
She be having fun, shit we wanna have fun
Seen her early in the morning looking bad as hell
Gon' be looking really funny when her shit don't sell
Airport, 'bout to miss a flight
Four carry-ons talking 'bout "pack light"
Oo, please, o, please give the queen her tea
I only come to the show cause i get in free

Friends, fans, artist must meet
Which one are you which one are me?
Fans, friends, and artist must meet
Which 1 are you ?
ARTIST
Folk in my face cause I'm a supastar
Niggass hang around cause of who I are
Get a lot of love cause of what I got
Say they happy for me, but they really not
Sell a lot of records and I roll a Benz
Fall up in the spot, now I'm losing friends
All I wanna do is give the world my heart
Record label trying to make me compromise my art
Make a million dollars, make a million mo '
Tax time come around, still a nigga po'
I wanna say wait, but I'm scared to ask
The world start spinning and it's moving fast
Try to stay sane, it's the price of fame
Spending my life trying to numb the pain
I shake that load off and sing the song
Liberate the mind and I go on homeEmbed

songs.full_title: U Don't Have To Call by Erykah Badu
songs.title: U Don’t Have To Call

description.plain: “U Don’t Have To Call” finds Erykah Badu doing a pseudo-cover of the well-known song by Usher, but re-writing her own freeform lyrics. The track mimicks the blips and sirens typical of The Neptunes‘ early 2000s production. The song ends after exactly two-minutes; such short tracks are typical in this mixtape format.

songs.full_title: Kiss Me on My Neck by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Kiss Me on My Neck

description.plain: Badu expresses her desire for a partner that will be confident enough to openly display their affection for her while still being able to “build” with her on subjects like Supreme Mathematics, which she has talked about on songs such as her hit debut single “On & On”.

[Chant Part 2]

[Monologue]
I don't have to tell you things aren't good. Everybody knows things aren't good. We know  the air is unfit to breathe and our food is unfit to eat. Young punks are running the street. No one knows just what to do and there's no end to it.  The dollar buys a penny's worth, banks are going under, cobblers keeping a gun under the counter. We sit watching our idiot boxes while some local anchorman tells us that today we've had eighteen murders and  eighty violent crimes, as if that were the way things are supposed to be. We know times are bad—worse than bad. People are crazy. It's like everything everywhere is going utterly mad, so we never leave our homes. We sit in our comfy abodes while the world is getting smaller and  we say, "C'mon, at least leave us alone in our family rooms. Let me have my microwave and flat screen and my 20-inch wheels and I won't say anything. Just leave us alone." Well, I'm not gonna leave you alone. I want you to get angry! I don't want you to riot. I don't want you to protest. I don't want you to write to your senator because I won't know what to tell you to tell him. I don't know what to do about the recession and the inflation and the crime in the street. All I know is that you've got to get mad. You've got to say, "I'm a human being, damn it! My life has value!"5Embed

songs.full_title: Turn Me Away (Get Munny) by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Turn Me Away (Get Munny)

description.plain: This funky track was the second single off of New Amerykah Part Two (Return of the Ankh). This song combines elements of Sylvia Striplin’s “You Can’t Turn Me Away” with the song that sampled it, Junior M.A.F.I.A. and The Notorious B.I.G.’s “Get Money”. The song was packaged in a music video along with the remix version of “Window Seat” featuring Rick Ross.

songs.title: Sometimes

description.plain: “Sometimes” is a song about liking someone while also disliking them at the same time and struggling with that feeling. This song was a base for her song “Ye Yo”, which was released on her Live album in 1997 and on the Hav Plenty soundtrack in 1998. The track was originally produced for Black Thought of The Roots, but eventually featured only Badu.

songs.title: Dial’Afreaq

description.plain:
“Dial-Afreaq” is a three-minute track from Erykah Badu’s But You Cain’t Use My Phone mixtape. After a lengthy introduction highlighting the plight of cell phone radiation causing large swaths of bees to die unexpectedly, an 80’s freestyle track begins.

Erykah Badu raps a single freestyle verse in a heavily-effected, phased, robotic voice. With its futuristic computer sound effects and “Planet Rock”-influenced sound, it both embraces Afrofuturism and a throwback to the synth-driven 80’s funk music of Cameo, Zapp & Roger, The Dazz Band, and Midnight Star.

songs.title: My Life

description.plain: “My Life” is one of the songs – along with “On & On” and “Appletree” – that Erykah recorded for a three-song demo in 1995. “On & On” and “Appletree” were both released as singles from Erykah’s 1997 debut, Baduizm, but “My Life” was shelved. Erykah returned to the song in 1998 during her sessions for Mama’s Gun when she was collaborating with producer J. Dilla, who helped give the song a “totally different beat” than its original form.

songs.title: Telephone

description.plain:
The final track on New Amerykah, Pt. 1, “Telephone” is an incredibly moving tribute to legendary producer and rapper James Dewitt Yancey, better known as Jay Dee or J Dilla, who died on February 10, 2006, aged 32. J Dilla was suffering from thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, a rare blood disease, and possibly lupus. He had been confined to a wheelchair since 2005, but continued producing from his final home at his mother’s house until his passing.

The writing and production on “Telephone” were handled by the reunited team of James Poyser, Badu and Questlove (credited on the song by their birth names of Erica Wright and Ahmir Khalid Thompson, respectively) who, along with J Dilla, collaborated extensively in the early 2000s, notably on Erykah’s sophmore album Mama’s Gun. All four had been close friends in addition to working together.

Few of Dilla’s friends knew the severity of his illness prior to his passing. Badu, who met Dilla in 1998 after being introduced to him by her boyfriend at the time, frequent Dilla collaborator Common, described the emotional genesis of “Telephone”:

“Common didn’t tell me, Dilla told him not to tell. And I didn’t know until the end how sick he was. I knew he had lupus but didn’t know how bad. So he was like that until the end, making beats and smoking blunts. … It was a very surreal moment when we heard Dilla had died. … We express ourselves through music and that day we recorded this song "Telephone”. … It was based on a story Dilla’s mother told me. Dilla would hallucinate often – he would be talking to someone when nobody was there. His mom would ask who he was talking to and he’d say: ‘Ol’ Dirty Bastard.’  ‘So what was he saying?’ ‘He was telling me what bus to get on when I cross over. He said: ‘Don’t get on the red bus, get on the white bus. The red bus looks fun, but that’s not the one’.‘ So Dilla’s mother told me that and when we were in the studio the night we heard about his passing, we paid homage to him, resting in beats, by writing that song “Telephone”.“

http://youtu.be/WzgODI4osy4
The song contains ghostly, faded versions of Dilla’s signature air horn drop, itself a sample from Mantronix’s “King of the Beats”. Dilla’s air horn has become a kind of totem in hip-hop culture used to evoke his memory. It was used by Dilla on most of his productions after 2005:
http://youtu.be/3G7GBYbxf8E?t=19s

Erykah alludes to Dilla on two other songs from New Amerykah, Pt. 1: “The Healer” and “My People”.

songs.full_title: Mr. Telephone Man by Erykah Badu
songs.title: Mr. Telephone Man

description.plain:
“Mr. Telephone Man” is an atmospheric song from Erykah Badu’s 2015 commercial mixtape release But You Caint Use My Phone filled with telecommunication-themed songs and interludes.

This atmospheric track reaches back over 3 decades to borrow heavily from New Edition’s 1984 hit single Mr. Telephone Man. Though Erykah doesn’t re-sing the song’s original verses, she makes sure not to close the song without reciting a line from poor, dejected Michael Bivins‘ monologue: “I dialed the right number, but I still couldn’t get through!”

songs.title: Amerykahn Promise

description.plain: New Amerykah Part One is an esoteric concept album titled as a pun on Badu’s first name and a reflection of the record’s political leanings. It features social commentary and themes related to the plight of the African-American community, including poverty, urban violence, complacency, and cultural identity. The record’s densely produced music incorporates hip hop, soul, funk, jazz, and electronica styles.

description.plain: After pairing with Common on the Grammy Award-winning “Love of My Life (An Ode to Hip-Hop)”, Erykah Badu calls in the ladies and dusts off her rap skills to rhyme alongside Queen Latifah, Bahamadia, and Angie Stone, who was featured on the song sampled here, the 1979 track “Funk You Up” by The Sequence.

description.plain:
“Incense” is number 10 on “New Amerykah, Part Two: Return Of The Ankh”.
The song is the follow-up of Badu’s “Fall In Love” and precedes 10-minute song “Out My Mind, Just in Time”.

This Badu’s song contains a sample of Frank Ricotti’s “Vibes”, released in 1981.

songs.title: The Cell

songs.full_title: The Grind by Erykah Badu (Ft. ​dead prez)
songs.title: The Grind

description.plain: Erykah Badu connects with hip-hop group dead prez on this track about the struggle—or “the grind"—of working a low-paying job to barely pay the bills while contemplating getting more cash faster through potentially illegal means.

songs.embed_content: Read “The Grind” by Erykah Badu on Genius

annotatable.title: The Grind

body.plain: Erykah Badu connects with hip-hop group dead prez on this track about the struggle—or “the grind"—of working a low-paying job to barely pay the bills while contemplating getting more cash faster through potentially illegal means.

songs.lyrics:
The Grind LyricsSteady On the Grind

Every day is a struggle
How to hustle some doe
If you was raised in the hood
Well then you already know
It be days that be good
But mostly money be slow
Have you ever been hungry before?

Steady on the grind Stead on the grind
‘Cause I got to make it happen
My family depending on me

Steady on the grind Steady on the grind
‘Cause I got to make it happen
‘ain't nobody gone do it for me
Ha ooh wa ooh ha ooh wa ooh
Ha ooh wa ooh ha ooh wa ooh

Steady on the grind
Daily on the grind
Money on my mind
So heavy on my mind So heavy on my mind

[Verse 1 – M-1]
Well, I'm a freedom fighter.  It's killa
Keep it Marcus Garvey, People Army guerrilla
Economic development—down for manual labor
Revolutionary hustler, fund raiser
Catch me doing outreach
See me running the streets
Politically educated but never graduated
Call me Doc like Mutulu Shakur, fight for the poor
Have you ever been hungry before?  Nigga, fa sure
Mommy got a job making 'bout six somethin' an hour
She became the breadwinner when daddy was unemployed
Working forty-plus hours and kissing ass
Seeming like the only honest way she can get some cash
She struggglin', she don't know I be hustlin' pulling my own weight
I be hearing them fuss and fightin' at night mad late
Over economics, it's logic—meaning they don't got it
Living in the projects, money's the only object
She makes $280 a week, standing on her feet
The ends ain't even meetin', the family ain't eatin'
And the taxes is ten percent, the rest is for the rent
Then crime is what you get and niggas is innocent
See, it really ain't about if you eatin' or not eatin'
It's freedom or not freedom, breathin' or not breathin'
'Nother day, 'nother way, 'nother dollar spent
Gotta make a revolution out of fifteen centEmbed

songs.title: Reprise (Live)
songs.embed_content: Read “Reprise (Live)” by Erykah Badu on Genius
songs.lyrics:
Reprise (Live) LyricsY’all know what a cypher is? It’s all kinds of cyphers. But a cypher can be represented by a circle, which consists of how many degrees? What? 360 degrees. And my cypher keeps moving like a rolling stone […] my cypher represents myself or the atoms in my body and the rolling stone represents the Earth. The atoms in the body rotate at the same rate on the same axis that the Earth rotates, giving us a direct connection with the place we call Earth; therefore, we can call ourselves Earth

You surprise me day and night
You keep me guessing day and night
Day and night (oh) day and night
I'll keep you in my heart no matter what happens
I promise you I'll never let you down
Even when you just don't know
And your feeling down
I'll be their for you
You surprise me day and night
You keep me guessing day and night
Day and night (oh) day and nightEmbed

songs.full_title: Props To The Lonely People by Erykah Badu (Ft. Bilal)
songs.title: Props To The Lonely People
songs.title_with_featured: Props To The Lonely People (Ft. Bilal)

description.plain:
‘Props To The Lonely People’ is an outtake from the Mama’s Gun sessions. The interlude – a duet with Bilal – originally appeared as the eighth track, between the songs “Cleva” and “Time’s A Wastin'”. However, in a last-minute decision, the sequence of the tracks were changed, which made the interlude no longer fit the album. Nonetheless, the lyrics and credits still appear in the booklet, as well as the original tracklisting. This track shuffle appeared unprofessional, considering she had three years to make this album.

The edited tracklist only appeared on the disk. The only explanation for the change-of-order is a note from Erykah written on the disk:

I changed the sequence at the last minute. Peace, E. Badu

The original tracklisting was:


Hey Sugah
Booty
Kiss Me On My Neck (Hesi)
Didn’t Cha Know
My Life
… & On
Cleva
Props To The Lonely People
Time’s A Wastin'
A.D. 2000
Penitentiary Philosophy
Orange Moon

In Love With You (feat. Stephen Marley)
Bag Lady
Green Eyes
